keyText:
quantity.

the amount of something.

They monitor both the quantity and the quality of materials used.

expert.

someone who has a particular skill or who knows a lot about a particular subject.

a safety/health/computer expert

stir.

to mix a drink by moving it around with a spoon or a stick.

The latest economic figures have stirred fears of growing inflation.

quality.

a feature of a substance or material.

the addictive qualities of tobacco

declare.

to announce officially that something is true or happening.

Australia declared its support for the agreement.

lightly.

without using much force or pressure.

Her hands rested lightly on his shoulders.

serious.

bad or dangerous enough to make you worried.

a serious illness/accident/injury: a serious head injury

frequent.

happening often.

Their arguments were becoming more and more frequent.

therefore.

as a result of the reason that has just been mentioned.

The new boots are lighter and softer, and therefore more comfortable to wear.

predict.

to say what you think will happen in the future.

They’re predicting heavy rain for tomorrow.

conclusion.

something that you decide is true after thinking about it carefully and looking at all the evidence.

reach/draw a conclusion: Hubble reached the conclusion that the universe was expanding.

spoil.

to affect something in a way that makes it worse, less attractive, or less enjoyable.

Radio towers spoiled the view.

accent.

a way of saying words that shows what country, region, or social class someone comes from.

a Brooklyn accent

complaint.

a written or spoken statement in which someone says they are not satisfied with something.

make/file/lodge a complaint: I intend to make a complaint.

flour.

a white or brown powder made by crushing grains. Flour is used for making bread, cakes, pasta, etc..

Add two tablespoons of flour.

attention.

the interest or thought that you give to something you are listening to or watching.

The speaker was dull and their attention soon wandered.

admire.

to have a feeling of great respect for someone or something.

I’ve always admired her dedication and commitment.

regret.

to feel sorry or sad that something has happened.

We regret any inconvenience caused by the delay.

wonder.

to think about something because you want to know more facts or details about it.

“How did they find out?” she wondered.

society.

people in general living together in organized communities, with laws and traditions controlling the way that they behave toward one another.

Society has to be prepared to support its elderly people.

essay.

a short piece of writing by a student on a particular subject.

essay on/about: We have to write an essay about Romantic poetry.

goods.

objects produced for sale.

a store specializing in leather goods

suppose.

to believe that something is probably true, based on your experience, your knowledge, and any other information that you have.

She was about 35, Dexter supposed.

captain.

the person in charge of a ship or aircraft.

We were invited to dine with the captain of the ship.

shine.

if the sun shines, it produces a bright light and the weather is usually warm.

The sun was shining brightly.

wrap.

to cover something by putting something such as paper or cloth around it.

Keep the cheeses fresh by wrapping each one individually.

continent.

one of the very large areas of land on Earth that are usually divided into several countries.

the North American continent

emergency.

an unexpected situation involving danger in which immediate action is necessary.

We always carry a medical kit for emergencies.

strict.

someone who is strict has definite rules that they expect people to obey completely.

He’s quite a strict coach, but we all like him.

manage.

to succeed in doing something, especially something that needs a lot of effort or skill.

I don’t know how you manage.

silence.

complete quiet.

The owl’s cry cut through the silence in the forest.

branch.

a part of a tree that grows out of its trunk  (=main stem) with leaves, flowers, or fruit growing on it. A very small branch is called a twig.

The wind rustled the bare branches of the trees.

session.

a period of time used for a particular activity.

A question-and-answer session will be held after the lecture.

grateful.

feeling that you want to thank someone because they have given you something or have done something for you.

Thanks for coming with me. I’m really grateful.

alive.

living and not dead.

My father died last year but my mother is still alive.

reduce.

to make something smaller or less in size, amount, importance, etc..

Try to reduce the amount of fat in your diet.

dull.

boring, or not interesting.

a dull lecture

zone.

an area that has an important or typical feature.

the coastal/earthquake zone

mystery.

something that you are not able to understand, explain, or get information about.

I just can’t think who she could have been – it’s a mystery.

enemy.

someone who is opposed to someone else and tries to do them harm.

He must hide from his enemies while he is weak.

arrange.

to make plans for something to happen, for example by agreeing a time and place.

I’m trying to arrange a meeting with their sales director.

select.

to choose someone or something from a group.

You can select one of four colors.

taste.

the flavor that something creates in your mouth when you eat or drink it.

I love the taste of chocolate.

deliver.

to take something, especially goods or letters, to a place.

The package was delivered this morning.

tin.

a chemical element that is a soft, light silver metal, often used for covering iron or steel. Its symbol is Sn..

a cookie tin

damage.

physical harm caused to something so that it is broken, spoiled, or injured.

Mr. Charlton surveyed the damage caused by the bulldozer.

discover.

to find out something that you did not know before.

The two men decided to discover the truth for themselves.

effect.

a change that is produced in one person or thing by another.

an adverse/beneficial effect  (=a bad/good effect): East German companies were suffering the adverse effects of German economic union.

owe.

if you owe someone money, you have to give them a particular amount of money because you have bought something from them or have borrowed money from them. Money that you owe is called a debt.

Tell me how much I owe, and I’ll give it to you.

despite.

used for saying that something happens even though something else might have prevented it.

Three more nuclear power stations were built despite widespread opposition.

awake.

not sleeping.

I’ve been awake for hours.

review.

to study or examine a situation, policy, or idea again in order to decide whether it is suitable or satisfactory.

The progress of each child must be regularly reviewed.

flag.

a piece of cloth decorated with the pattern and colors that represent a country or organization. A flag is often hung from a pole called a flagpole.

The American flag is called the stars and stripes.

destroy.

to damage something so severely that it no longer exists or can never return to its normal state.

Half the world’s rain forests have already been destroyed.

plain.

easily seen or understood.

Hugh’s message was short, but the meaning was plain enough.

sharp.

a sharp object has an edge that can cut or an end that is pointed.

Cut the melon in half using a sharp knife.

advance.

progress or an instance of progress in science, technology, human knowledge, etc..

In spite of all its advances, medical science still knows little about the brain.

forecast.

a statement about what is likely to happen, based on available information and usually relating to the weather, business, or the economy.

The weather forecast is for a dry sunny day tomorrow.

sensible.

reasonable and practical.

This seems to be a sensible way of dealing with the problem.

annual.

happening once a year.

an annual festival/vacation/report

cotton.

cloth made from the white fibers of a plant called a cotton plant.

fields of cotton

drop.

to deliberately let something fall.

drop something off something: The children were dropping stones off the bridge.

display.

an arrangement of things for people to look at.

a window display

shoot.

to fire a gun.

We were ordered not to shoot until he gave the signal.

disease.

an illness that affects people or animals, especially one that is caused by an infection.

liver/heart/lung disease: leading causes of heart disease

aloud.

loud enough for other people to hear.

The teacher would read aloud to the group.

particular.

used for emphasizing that you are talking about one specific person or thing and not anyone or anything else.

Are there any particular topics that you would like me to explain further?

waste.

the failure to use something valuable in an effective way, so that it does not produce the benefits that it could.

All this uneaten food – what a waste!

intend.

to have a plan in your mind to do something.

intend to do something: What do you intend to do about this?

disappear.

if someone or something disappears, they move somewhere where they can no longer be seen.

Dave said good night to everyone and quickly disappeared upstairs.

freeze.

if water freezes, or if something freezes it, it gets very cold and changes into ice.

The lake freezes in winter.

ashamed.

feeling guilty or embarrassed because you have done something wrong, or think that you have not reached a standard that people expect.

I regret the incident and am deeply ashamed and embarrassed.

mention.

to say something during a conversation, but not discuss it much or give many details.

He didn’t mention her all evening.

individual.

existing or considered separately from other people or things.

Individual members of the cast contributed greatly to the show’s success.

behave.

to do things in a particular way.

The children behaved very badly.

gain.

to get or achieve something, usually as a result of a lot of effort.

Extremist political parties gained 11% of the vote.

hole.

a space dug in the surface of the ground.

Workers dug a 30-foot hole in the ground.

continue.

to keep doing something without stopping.

Doctors advised him to continue the treatment for another six weeks.

object.

a thing that you can see and touch that is not alive and is usually solid.

The boat was bumping against some solid object underwater.

meanwhile.

from now until a time or event in the future.

The hurricane will reach the island this evening. Meanwhile, residents are being evacuated.

item.

an individual thing, usually one of several things in a group or on a list.

customers who pay high prices for luxury items

property.

things, especially valuable things, that are owned by someone.

personal property: The books are my personal property.

disagree.

to have an opinion that is different from the opinion that another person has.

Teenagers and their parents often disagree.

elbow.

the part in the middle of your arm, where it bends.

She sat with her elbows on the table.

port.

an area of water where ships stop, including the buildings around it. A harbor is the same thing but smaller and is intended for smaller boats.

in port: We’ll have to spend 10 days in port for repairs.

lack.

a situation in which you do not have any, or enough, of something that you need or want.

lack of: The game was canceled because of lack of interest.

row.

a series of people or things arranged in a straight line.

The teacher stopped in front of a little boy in the front row.

ability.

the fact of being able to do something.

ability to do something: Tiredness can seriously impair your ability to drive.

valley.

a low area of land between mountains or hills, usually with a river flowing through it.

the Ohio River Valley

solve.

to find a solution to something that is causing difficulties.

solve a crisis/dispute/conflict: It is hoped that diplomatic efforts can solve the crisis peacefully.

convenient.

easy to do, or not causing problems or difficulties.

If it’s convenient, call me tomorrow before noon.

feed.

to give food to a person or an animal.

We’ve been feeding the ducks on the river.

sew.

to make or repair clothes using a needle and thread.

sew a skirt/hem

secret.

a piece of information that is known by only a small number of people, and is deliberately not told to other people.

It cannot remain a secret much longer.

giant.

a very large and successful company.

the Dutch electronics giant Phillips

steep.

a steep slope rises quickly and is difficult to climb.

a steep slope/hill/bank/path

agency.

a government department, or an organization connected with a government, that deals with a particular subject.

the official Chinese news agency

excitement.

the feeling of being excited.

The long wait only added to our excitement.

injure.

to hurt someone and cause damage to their body.

Nine people died and 54 were injured in the accident.

load.

something that a person or animal carries, especially a large amount of things.

The men were struggling with their heavy loads.

escape.

to get away from a place where you are in danger.

Three people died in the fire, but John escaped through the bedroom window.

forever.

for all time in the future, or for as long as you can imagine.

They promised to love each other forever.

nowhere.

not in any place, or not to any place.

Nowhere on earth is free from ecological damage.

mood.

the way that someone is feeling, for example whether they are happy, sad, or angry.

He listens to rock or country music, depending on his mood.

crash.

if a plane crashes, or if someone crashes it, it falls from the sky.

A 727 crashed near Heidelberg.

fuel.

a substance such as oil, gas, coal, or wood that produces heat or power when it is burned. Coal and wood are sometimes called solid fuel.

Drivers are being encouraged to save fuel.

perform.

to do something in front of an audience in order to entertain them, for example by acting in a play or singing.

The opera was first performed in 1992.

grab.

to take hold of something in a rough or rude way.

He grabbed the knife before I could get to it.

sour.

with a taste like a lemon.

Use a quart of sour pie cherries.

calm.

not affected by strong emotions such as excitement, anger, shock, or fear.

An hour after the accident, I was starting to feel calmer.

value.

the amount that something is worth, measured especially in money.

You can’t put a value on a human life.

exact.

done, made, or described in a very thorough way, with all the details correct.

This is an exact replica of the original ship.

attach.

to fasten or join one thing to another.

attach something to something: Attach the rope to the branch of a tree.

landscape.

an area of land that is beautiful to look at or that has a particular type of appearance.

a green, rural landscape

shortly.

soon, or happening only a short period of time after something.

We’re going to break for lunch very shortly.

compare.

to consider how things or people are similar and how they are different.

compare something with/to something: Just compare the one that has been cleaned with the others.

lively.

full of energy and enthusiasm.

a lively group of students

local.

in or related to the area that you live in, or to the particular area that you are talking about.

Ask for the book in your local library.

convince.

to make someone believe that something is true.

convince someone of something: He failed to convince the jury of his innocence.

attend.

to be present at an event or activity.

Everyone in the office was expected to attend.

opinion.

the attitude that you have toward something, especially your thoughts about how good it is.

opinion of: What is your opinion of her latest novel?

efficient.

something that is efficient works well and produces good results by using the available time, money, supplies, etc. in the most effective way.

The new machine is far more efficient than the old one.

mess.

a situation in which a place is dirty or not neat.

Your room is a mess; please pick up your toys.

explore.

to travel to a place in order to learn about it or to search for something valuable such as oil.

The town is a good base from which to explore this charming corner of New England.

length.

a measurement of how long something is in size.

Cut the cloth to the required length.

handle.

to take action in order to deal with a difficult situation.

The government was criticized for the way it handled the crisis.

curious.

someone who is curious wants to find out about something.

I didn’t mean to pry. I’m just curious. That’s all.

sight.

the ability to see using your eyes.

I’m having laser treatment to improve my sight.

account.

an arrangement in which a bank takes care of your money. You can deposit  (=put in) or withdraw  (=take out) money when you need to.

There was only $50 in his bank account.

base.

the bottom part, edge, or surface of something.

a tall cliff, with a narrow footpath at its base

importance.

the fact of being important, or the degree to which something or someone is important.

By 1800, the monarchy had declined in importance.

obvious.

clear to almost anyone.

The most obvious explanation is not always the correct one.

within.

inside an area, building, room, or space.

The ticket gives students unlimited free travel within the U.K.

hunt.

to kill animals for food or for their skin or other parts, or for sport.

Crocodiles were hunted and killed for their teeth.

rather.

to a fairly large degree.

I realize that I’ve been rather stupid and selfish.

equal.

the same in value, amount, or size.

All the workers have an equal share in the profits.

period.

an amount of time during which something happens.

The long dry period ended with torrential rain.

revise.

to change your opinion or judgment of someone or something.

The text has been revised and published in a new edition.

solution.

a way to solve a problem or to deal with a bad situation.

solution to/for: UN leaders are working hard to find a peaceful solution to the conflict.

pause.

to stop moving or stop what you are doing for a short time before starting again.

She paused at the door and then left.

range.

a number of different things that are of the same general type.

range of: The speaker will deal with a broad a range of issues affecting professional women.

accompany.

to go with someone to a place or event.

Children must be accompanied by an adult.

annoy.

to make someone feel slightly angry or impatient.

I don’t dislike her, but she just annoys me sometimes.

palace.

a very large building, especially one used as the official home of a royal family, president, or important religious leader.

the presidential palace

silly.

showing that you are not intelligent, not serious, not thinking carefully, etc..

a silly mistake

leaf.

a flat thin green part of a tree or plant that grows on a branch or stem.

A light breeze stirred the leaves of the tall oak tree outside her window.

rock.

the hard solid substance that forms part of the Earth’s surface.

Rainwater flows through soil and porous rock to reach underground streams.

somehow.

in some way or by some method that you do not know or understand exactly.

Somehow he managed to pass all his final exams.

respect.

a feeling of admiration that you have for someone because of their personal qualities, their achievements, or their status, and that you show by treating them in a polite and kind way.

respect for: Students show their respect for the teacher by not talking.

bunch.

a group of people.

They’re a great bunch who have made me feel welcome.

basic.

forming the main or most important part of something, without which it cannot really exist.

Rice is the basic ingredient of the dish.

thick.

a thick object or material has a long distance between two opposite sides, edges, or surfaces.

She was wearing a thick wool sweater.

cruel.

someone who is cruel enjoys causing pain to other people or animals, or enjoys making them unhappy or upset.

a cruel parent

battle.

a fight between two armies in a war.

one of the bloodiest battles of World War II

wing.

one of the parts on a bird, insect, or bat that move up and down and allow it to fly. Birds have two wings, but insects have either two or four wings.

a moth’s delicate wings

confident.

someone who is confident believes in their own abilities and so does not feel nervous or frightened.

a confident mood/smile/manner

pot.

a deep round metal container used for cooking food in on a stove.

a set of pots and pans

certain.

having no doubts that something is true.

I’m not absolutely certain, but I think I’m right.

relative.

having a particular quality when compared with something else.

There was relative calm after the violence of the previous night.

create.

to make something new or original that did not exist before.

How do I create a new file?

indeed.

used for adding a statement that supports and increases the effect of what you have just said.

Brendel is certainly a fine musician. Indeed, I regard him as one of the greatest pianists of our time.

stream.

a small narrow river.

A path runs alongside the stream.

voice.

the sounds that someone makes when they speak.

A female voice answered the phone.

ruin.

to destroy or severely damage something.

You’ll completely ruin the flowers if you touch them.

broad.

wide.

He was of medium height, but had very broad shoulders.

search.

an attempt to find something.

Despite a thorough search, they found no drugs on him.

disabled.

.

locate.

to find out the exact place where someone or something is.

Engineers are still trying to locate the flaw.

essential.

completely necessary.

In a large organization, good internal communication is essential.

tap.

to touch someone or something gently and to move them slightly, or to make a soft knocking sound.

Several young men were tapping away at keyboards  (=using computers).

background.

the type of career, training, or education that someone has had.

His musical background helps him a lot in his job.

bury.

to put someone’s dead body in the ground during a funeral ceremony.

All his family are buried in the same cemetery.

peak.

the time when something is at its highest or greatest level.

The city’s population is about 400,000, down from a peak of 750,000 in the late 1960s.

pregnant.

if a woman is pregnant, she has a baby developing inside her body.

You should not smoke if you are pregnant.

communicate.

to express thoughts, feelings, or information to another person or animal, for example by speaking or writing.

How do whales communicate?

poem.

a piece of writing using beautiful or unusual language arranged in fixed lines that have a particular beat and often rhyme.

a book of poems about his childhood

direct.

involving only the two people or things mentioned and with no one or nothing else coming in between.

Employees have little direct contact with management.

raw.

raw food has not been cooked, or has not been thoroughly cooked.

raw meat

rob.

to take money or property illegally from a person or place, often using threats or violence.

They were planning to rob the museum.

speech.

a formal occasion when someone speaks to an audience.

He began his speech by outlining his plans for the coming year.

gentle.

a gentle person is kind and calm.

Joe is such a gentle, loving boy.

report.

a spoken or written account that gives information about a particular subject, situation, or event.

According to the police report, the victim died of a knife wound.

public.

available for people in general to use.

public transportation

argue.

if people argue, they speak to each other in an angry way because they disagree.

Those girls are always arguing!

generation.

all the members of a family who are of a similar age and whose parents are of a similar age.

My mother was the only one in her generation to go to university.

custom.

something that people do that is traditional or usual.

local customs and traditions

common.

happening frequently, or existing in large amounts or numbers.

Mergers and takeovers have become increasingly common in recent years.

proud.

feeling happy about your achievements, your possessions, or people who you are connected with.

proud of: We’re so proud of her for telling the truth.

apply.

to make an official request for a job or a place to study at a college or university, or for permission to do or have something.

We advertised three jobs, and over 50 people applied.

narrow.

small in width, especially when compared to how high or long something is.

a narrow strip of land/water

unless.

used for saying that if something does not happen, something else will happen or be true as a result.

I can’t help you unless you tell me what’s wrong.

slip.

if you slip, your feet slide accidentally and you lose your balance or fall over.

Margaret slipped and broke her arm.

beat.

to hit someone violently several times.

They were arrested for beating their children.

rude.

not polite.

I don’t want to seem rude, but I’d rather be alone.

accurate.

correct or true in every detail.

We need to get an accurate estimate of what the new building will cost.

edge.

the part of something that is farthest from its center.

Bring the two edges together and fasten them securely.

religion.

the belief in the existence of a god or gods.

Religion is something we always argue about.

duty.

a legal or moral obligation.

He has a duty under the terms of his contract to pay rent.

hang.

to put something somewhere so that the top part is held in position but the bottom part is loose and can move easily.

Hang your jacket there.

register.

to put your name and other information on an official list in order to be allowed to vote, study, stay in a hotel, etc..

Where do we go to register?

chin.

.

friendship.

a relationship between people who are friends.

The reunion gave us a chance to renew old friendships.

candidate.

one of the people competing in an election.

the Democratic/Republican candidate

decrease.

to become less.

The number of people visiting the park has decreased significantly.

pill.

a small piece of solid medicine that you swallow with water.

sleeping/contraceptive/vitamin pills

van.

a vehicle used for carrying goods or several people. It is usually larger than a car and smaller than a truck, and the back part is enclosed.

We’ll have to rent a van to move all this stuff.

crop.

a plant grown for food, usually on a farm.

That year, crop failure led to widespread famine.

law.

an official rule that people must obey.

The new law will be passed by the Senate in the spring.

awful.

used for emphasizing how unpleasant someone or something is.

The smell was absolutely awful.

complain.

to say that you are not satisfied with something.

“It’s far too hot,” she complained.

ocean.

one of the large areas of salt water that cover most of the Earth.

the Atlantic/Pacific/Indian Ocean

cottage.

.

anxious.

worried because you think something bad might happen.

His silence made me anxious.

via.

going through one place on the way to another place.

They flew from New York to New Delhi via Frankfurt.

clap.

to hit your hands together many times to show that you liked something or admire someone.

At the end of the speech everyone clapped.

ceremony.

a formal public event with special traditions, actions, or words.

a ceremony to honor those who died in the war

although.

used for introducing a statement that makes your main statement seem surprising.

Although he’s got a good job now, he still complains.

operate.

if equipment operates, it works and does what it is intended to do.

The ventilation equipment was not operating properly.

stripe.

a line of one color on a background of a different color.

a white shirt with red stripes

faucet.

.

fever.

a medical condition in which the temperature of your body is very high and you feel sick.

What do you use to reduce fever in infants?

persuade.

to make someone agree to do something by giving them reasons why they should.

He did finally come with us, although it took a long time to persuade him.

pure.

a pure substance or material has nothing mixed with it that might spoil its quality or effect.

pure gold/alcohol

recommend.

to advise someone that they should do something.

recommend (that): I recommend that you buy a more powerful computer.

tip.

a narrow or pointed end, especially of something long or thin.

tip of: the tip of your nose/finger

research.

the detailed study of something in order to discover new facts, especially in a university or scientific institution.

Recent research shows that babies in the womb can be influenced by music.

contest.

a competition, especially one in which people’s skill in a particular activity or sport is tested.

a contest between the two top-rated tennis players in the world

extraordinary.

very unusual and surprising.

It’s an extraordinary story.

switch.

to change from one thing to another, or to make something do this.

Then he switched sides and turned against his former allies.

prevent.

to stop something from happening.

Regular cleaning may help prevent infection.

rescue.

to save someone from a dangerous or unpleasant situation.

The crew of the tanker were rescued just minutes before it sank in heavy seas.

pronounce.

to say the sounds of letters or words.

I find some Japanese words very difficult to pronounce.

hide.

to put something in a place so that no one can find or see it.

hide something in/at/under etc. something: She hid the key in the drawer.

coast.

an area of land beside an ocean.

the east coast of the United States

fold.

to bend a piece of paper or cloth and press one part of it over another part.

Carrie folded the note and slid it into her purse.

fasten.

to close something such as a piece of clothing or a bag using the buttons, zipper, clip, etc. on it.

Please keep your seat belts fastened while the seat belt light is on.

fee.

money that you pay to a professional person or institution for their work.

Many doctors have a standard scale of fees.

wave.

a line of water that rises up on the surface of an ocean, lake, or river.

The boat was smashed by a huge wave.

youth.

the time in someone’s life when they are young.

In his youth, he had traveled and seen much of the world.

store.

a place that sells goods.

Some stores are overcharging their customers.

benefit.

extra money or other advantages that you get in addition to your salary from your employer as part of your job.

The benefits include medical insurance and a company car.

trick.

an unfair or unpleasant thing that you do in order to harm someone or to get an advantage for yourself.

a dirty/cruel/nasty trick: It was a very dirty trick to play on anyone.

transfer.

to move from one job, office, or department to another in the same company or organization.

transfer to: I’m transferring to our Tokyo office next year.

block.

a solid piece of wood, stone, ice, etc. with straight sides.

The baby was playing with wooden blocks.

divorce.

a legal way of ending a marriage.

I want a divorce.

firm.

solid but not hard.

The ground beneath our feet was fairly firm and not too muddy.

limit.

the largest or smallest amount, or the highest or lowest level, of something that is allowed.

speed/spending limits

challenge.

something that needs a lot of skill, energy, and determination to deal with or achieve, especially something you have never done before and will enjoy doing.

I was bored with my job and felt I needed a new challenge.

defend.

to protect someone or something from attack.

Thousands of young men came forward, willing to defend their country.

permit.

to allow someone to do something, or to allow something to happen.

The use of cell phones is not permitted inside the aircraft.

bet.

to risk an amount of money by saying what you think will happen, especially in a race or game. You lose the money if you are wrong and win more if you are right.

bet on: Thousands of people bet on the result of the game.

environment.

the natural world, including the land, water, air, plants, and animals, especially considered as something that is affected by human activity.

Industrial development is causing widespread damage to the environment.

dozen.

a set of 12 things or people.

a dozen red roses

lawyer.

.

operation.

a planned activity involving a lot of people, especially soldiers or police officers.

This was the biggest military operation in 20 years.

increase.

to become larger in amount or number.

Our costs increased dramatically over the last decade.

smell.

the pleasant or unpleasant quality of something that you notice when you breathe in through your nose.

This paint gives off a very strong smell.

comment.

a written or spoken remark giving an opinion.

I’ve had enough of your sarcastic comments.

weigh.

to have a particular weight.

Tell me Clare, how much do you weigh?

drag.

to pull something or someone along with difficulty, for example because they are heavy.

drag something down/along/through something: She dragged her suitcase to the car.

pleasure.

a feeling of happiness, enjoyment, or satisfaction.

He smiled with pleasure when she walked in.

step.

a short movement made by putting one foot in front of the other.

take/move a step: I am too tired to take another step.

opportunity.

a chance to do something, or a situation in which it is easy for you to do something.

I think this trip sounds like a wonderful opportunity.

recent.

happening or starting a short time ago.

a recent discovery/survey/study

nervous.

feeling excited and worried, or slightly afraid.

Driving on icy mountain roads makes me nervous.

truth.

the actual facts or information about something, rather than what people think, expect, or make up.

The truth may never be known.

arrest.

if the police arrest someone, they take that person to a police station because they believe he or she has committed a crime. Someone who has been arrested is under arrest, and if they are not allowed to leave, they are in custody.

Police raided the store at dawn, arresting six men and seizing hundreds of pirated CDs.

charge.

an amount of money that you have to pay, especially when you visit a place or when someone does something for you.

You will have to pay a small admission charge.

vote.

to formally express an opinion by choosing between two or more issues, people, etc..

vote for/in favor of/against: 68 percent of the union voted against striking.

retire.

to stop working, especially when you reach the age when you are officially too old to work.

retire from: He retired from the army last month.

flu.

a very common infectious disease that lasts a short time and makes you feel hot or cold, weak, and tired.

He’s in bed with flu.

distance.

the amount of space between two people or things.

distance from: It is important to consider distance from public transportation when buying a house.

breathe.

to take air into your lungs through your nose or mouth and let it out again.

He held her so tightly she could hardly breathe.

section.

something, or a group of things, that forms part of a larger group.

section of: He condemned the campaign that is being mounted in some sections of the press.

blow.

if wind or air blows, the air moves.

The wind was blowing from the sea.

succeed.

to achieve something that you planned to do or attempted to do.

We all want to make the peace process succeed.

altogether.

used for showing that a total number or amount includes everyone or everything.

Altogether, about 50 NATO aircraft took part in the attack.

proper.

appropriate for the purpose or situation.

You have to have the proper tools for the job.

description.

a statement about what someone or something is like.

a brief description of the area

trouble.

problems, worries, or difficulties.

The company has been experiencing serious financial troubles recently.

author.

someone who writes books, articles, etc., especially as their job.

Nobel Prize winning author, Alexander Solzhenitsyn

pile.

a number of things put on top of each other.

She sorted her clothes into neat piles.

average.

the amount, level, standard, etc. that is typical of a group of people or things.

Incomes here are nowhere near the national average.

afford.

if you can afford something, you have enough money to be able to pay for it. This word usually follows “can,” “could,” or “be able to”.

I’m not sure how they are able to afford such expensive vacations.

profession.

a job that you need special skills and qualifications to do, especially one with high social status.

the medical/legal/nursing/teaching profession

relax.

to rest and allow yourself to become calm.

Just sit down and try to relax for half an hour.

involve.

to include something as a necessary part of an activity, event, or situation.

The course involves a great deal of hard work.

concentrate.

to give all your attention to the thing you are doing.

I was sleeping badly and finding it hard to concentrate.

publish.

to produce something that people want to read, watch or play and make it available to the public.

In order for indie developers to publish a game on the Xbox Live Arcade they will be required to partner with Microsoft Game Studios or a third-party publisher.

entertain.

to give a performance that people enjoy.

The children sang and danced to entertain the crowd.

encourage.

to suggest that someone does something that you believe would be good.

We encourage student participation in our classes.

demand.

to say in a very firm way that you want something.

Angry congressmen are demanding an inquiry into the deal.

sum.

an amount of money.

He was fined a sum of $1,000.

smooth.

completely even with no rough areas or lumps.

A baby’s skin is as smooth as silk.

produce.

to make or grow something, especially in large quantities and in order to be sold.

We are now producing the same quantity of goods with far fewer workers.

height.

the degree to which something is high or someone is tall.

He was about the same height as his wife.

officer.

someone with a position of power and authority in the military.

an army officer

advertise.

to try to persuade people to buy a product or service by announcing it on television, on the Internet, in newspapers, etc..

The company regularly advertises on TV.

regard.

to think of someone or something in a particular way.

regard someone/something as something: The nuclear reactors, which were regarded as dangerously out of date, were replaced.

defeat.

failure to win a competition or to succeed in doing something.

Wisconsin suffered a 23–7 defeat by Illinois.

wage.

an amount of money that you earn for working, usually according to how many hours or days you work each week or month.

daily/hourly/weekly wage

fix.

to repair something.

Jessica fixed my watch.

approve.

to have a positive feeling toward someone or something that you consider to be good or suitable.

You’re leaving college! Do your parents approve?

depend.

used when you cannot give a definite answer, because different things are possible in different situations.

it​/​that depends what/where/how etc.: “How much will I have to pay for a car?” “It depends what type of car you want.”

reward.

something good that happens or that you receive because of something that you have done.

reward for: Rewards for appropriate behavior can be successful in teaching children.

fault.

the fact of being responsible for a bad or unpleasant situation.

be someone’s fault: It’s my fault – I forgot to give him the message.

ancient.

very old.

an ancient city/book/tradition

shadow.

an area of darkness that is created when something blocks light.

The kids jumped out of the shadows, trying to scare us.

diagram.

a drawing that explains something.

diagram of: a diagram of the manufacturing process

brief.

lasting only for a short time.

Idaho experienced a brief period of population growth during the early nineties.

previous.

a previous event, period, or thing happened or existed before the one that you are talking about.

This issue was discussed in the previous chapter.

support.

to approve of an idea or of a person or organization and help them to be successful.

The United Nations has supported efforts to return the refugees peacefully.

roll.

to move forward while turning over and over.

The pencil went rolling across the floor.

army.

a large organization of soldiers who are trained to fight wars on land. Together with a country’s navy and air force, the army makes up the armed forces.

After graduating from school, he joined the army.

attract.

to make someone interested in something so that they do it or come to see or hear it.

The show attracts viewers from every sector of society.

fear.

the feeling that you have when you are frightened.

Edward knew it was dangerous, but he felt no fear.

asleep.

not awake.

Are you asleep yet?

interval.

a period of time between two events.

The normal interval between our meetings is six weeks.

decision.

a choice that you make after thinking carefully.

make a decision: The committee should make its decision later this week.

criminal.

someone who has committed a crime.

The system is designed to prevent criminals from reoffending.

organize.

to prepare or arrange an activity or event.

Who’s organizing the conference?

sleeve.

the part of a piece of clothing that covers your arm.

short/long sleeves: a dress with long sleeves

burn.

if a fire or flame burns, it produces light and heat.

A fire was burning in the hearth.

deaf.

not able to hear anything, or not able to hear very well. Many deaf people wear a hearing aid to help them hear. Deaf people often use their hands to communicate in sign language, and many can lip-read what other people are saying.

totally/partially deaf: She’s been totally deaf since birth.

dig.

to make a hole in earth or sand using your hands, a machine, or a tool, especially a shovel.

The children like to dig in the sand.

reply.

to say, write, or do something as an answer.

“I know,” Corbett replied quietly.

ingredient.

one of the foods or liquids that you use in making a particular meal.

Mix all the ingredients together and place them in a shallow dish.

pattern.

a series of actions or events that together show how things normally happen or are done.

pattern of: We examined patterns of behavior in young children.

explode.

to burst with a lot of force and a loud noise.

Bombs were exploding all over the city.

attitude.

someone’s opinions or feelings about something, especially as shown by their behavior.

The prevailing attitude at the time was antiwar.

skill.

the ability to do something well, usually as a result of experience and training.

I admired the skill and dedication of the nursing staff.

departure.

the time when an airplane, bus, or train leaves.

a 10 o’clock departure

fancy.

not plain or simple but with a lot of decorations or extra parts.

I wanted just a plain handbag, nothing fancy.

breath.

the air that goes in and out of your body through your nose or mouth.

He could feel her warm breath on his face.

shake.

to make many quick small movements up and down, or side to side.

Houses shook as a bomb exploded in the neighborhood.

aim.

to point a gun or an object you are throwing at something that you want to hit.

When given the order, the squad aimed their weapons.

employ.

to pay someone regularly to do a job for you or to work as a member of your organization.

They employ a nanny, cleaner, and gardener.

progress.

the process of developing or improving.

I’m worried about my son’s lack of progress in English.

patient.

someone who is receiving medical treatment.

Several patients complained about the treatment they received.

keen.

keen sight, hearing, etc. makes you very good at seeing things, hearing things, etc..

I have a very keen sense of smell.

loose.

not firmly fixed in position.

loose floorboards

generous.

giving people more of your time or money than is usual or expected.

Merton is clearly a warm and generous person.

resort.

a place that many people go to for a vacation.

a ski/seaside/mountain resort

product.

something that is made, grown, or obtained in large quantities so that it can be sold.

dairy/pharmaceutical/software products

contract.

a written legal agreement between two people or businesses that says what each must do for the other or give to the other.

After six months she was offered an employment contract.

knit.

to make something such as a piece of clothing using wool and sticks called knitting needles.

She reads and knits to pass the time.

crime.

an illegal activity or action.

commit a crime  (=do something illegal): She was unaware that she had committed a crime.

tear.

to pull something so that it separates into pieces or gets a hole in it, or to become damaged in this way.

It’s made of very thin material that tears easily.

choice.

the opportunity or right to choose between different things.

Our aim is to provide greater choice for consumers.

liquid.

a substance that can flow, has no fixed shape, and is not a solid or a gas.

a glass of colorless liquid

access.

the right or opportunity to have or use something that will bring you benefits.

access to: Access to up-to-date financial information is important to our success.

thief.

someone who steals something. An instance of stealing something is called a theft.

The thief stole a valuable painting from the museum.

recognize.

to know who the person is or what the thing is that you are seeing, hearing, etc. because you have seen, heard, etc. them before.

I hardly recognized you with a beard!

require.

to need someone or something.

Working with these children requires a great deal of patience.

connect.

to join two things together.

She carefully connected the two wires.

prove.

to provide evidence that shows that something is true.

prove (that): You have to prove you are sorry for what you’ve done.

confirm.

to prove that something is true.

The study confirms the findings of earlier research.

purpose.

the goal that someone wants to achieve, or that something is intended to achieve.

I use my boat mainly for leisure purposes.

social.

relating to activities that involve being with other people, especially activities that you do for pleasure.

a social activity/engagement/get-together

audience.

a group of people who have come to a place to see or hear a movie, performance, speech, etc. The people who watch a sports game or other large event are usually called spectators or the crowd.

Chaplin’s movies captivated audiences throughout the world.

sail.

if a boat sails, it moves across the surface of an ocean, lake, river, etc..

The yacht sailed into harbor.

culture.

activities involving music, literature, and other arts.

If you’re looking for culture, then Paris is the place for you.

tiny.

extremely small.

The floor was covered in tiny pieces of paper.

independent.

fair because of not being influenced by anyone else.

Seek independent legal advice before entering into an agreement.

kid.

a young adult.

a bunch of middle-class college kids

hero.

someone who has done something brave, for example saving a person’s life or risking their own life.

a war hero

district.

an area of a town or country.

They live in one of the most exclusive districts of Paris.

twin.

one of two children born at the same time to the same mother. Twins of the same sex who look exactly like each other are called identical twins. Twins that are not identical are called fraternal twins.

I have a twin brother and one sister.

appear.

to make other people think that you are something or feel something. Appear is a slightly more formal word than seem.

This job is not as easy as it first appeared.

provide.

to give someone something that they want or need.

Our office can provide information on the local area.

chapter.

one of the sections into which a book is divided. A chapter usually has a number or a title.

See Chapter Three for more details.

effort.

an attempt to do something that is difficult or that involves hard work.

an effort to do something: The restructuring was part of an effort to boost company profits.

rough.

with a surface that is not smooth.

The walls were built of dark rough stone.

attack.

a violent attempt to harm a person, animal, or place.

a vicious attack

disadvantage.

something that makes someone or something less effective, successful, or attractive.

Grants are available for projects that tackle disadvantage in deprived areas.

insist.

to say very firmly that something must happen or must be done.

You must see a doctor immediately – I insist.

apart.

if two people or things are apart, there is a space between them.

Stand with your feet apart.

yard.

.

guard.

someone whose job is to protect a place or person so that no one causes damage, steals anything, or escapes.

uniformed border guards

surround.

to be all around or on all sides of someone or something.

Can you name the states that surround Colorado?

iron.

.

forward.

in a position toward the front of a room or vehicle.

Let’s sit farther forward so we can see the stage better.

consider.

to think about something carefully before making a decision or developing an opinion.

She paused and considered for a moment.

attempt.

an effort to do something.

one last desperate attempt

ordinary.

normal or average, and not unusual or special.

He lives in an ordinary house in suburban Melbourne.

bay.

an area of the coast where the land curves inward.

The harbor lights were visible across the bay.

signature.

a person’s name written in a special way by that person.

collecting signatures for a petition

brave.

capable of dealing with danger or pain, without seeming to be frightened.

the brave soldiers who fought and died for their country

guilty.

ashamed and sorry because you have done something wrong.

You shouldn’t feel guilty all the time – you’ve done nothing to be ashamed of.

hire.

to pay someone to work for you.

I hired someone to paint the house.

issue.

a subject that people discuss or argue about, especially relating to society, politics, etc..

It’s a website devoted to environmental issues.

disappoint.

to make someone feel unhappy because something that they hoped for or expected did not happen or because someone or something was not as good as they expected.

I hate to disappoint you, but the cake’s all gone.

permission.

the right to do something that is given to you by someone in authority.

You are not allowed to camp here without permission.

bite.

to use your teeth to cut or break something, usually in order to eat it.

Stop biting your nails.

contain.

a container, envelope, room, etc. that contains something has something inside it.

The envelope contained a few dried rose petals.

though.

used for introducing a statement that makes your main statement seem surprising.

Though the U.K. is only a small country, it has played an important role in history.

vehicle.

a machine that you travel in or on, especially one with an engine that travels on roads, for example a car, bus, van, truck, or motorcycle.

Watch out for oncoming vehicles.

avoid.

to try not to go near someone or something.

We went early to avoid the crowds.

blank.

showing no emotion or no sign of understanding something or recognizing someone.

His eyes were blank and he barely responded to us.

spot.

the particular place where someone or something is.

We found him sitting in a sunny spot in the yard.

journalist.

someone whose job is to report the news for a newspaper, magazine, radio program, or television program.

an article by a leading sports journalist

divide.

to separate people or things into smaller groups or parts.

Divide the dough and roll out one part.

silent.

a silent person or group of people does not talk, laugh, or make any noise.

Everyone was totally silent as the president spoke.

otherwise.

used for saying that something is true except for the fact that you have just mentioned.

The driver suffered shock but was otherwise unhurt.

accept.

to take something that someone gives you.

It gives me great pleasure to accept this award.

protect.

to keep someone or something safe from harm, injury, damage, or loss.

Are you prepared to protect yourself in case of attack?

material.

cloth.

Her dress was made of a thin lacy material.

deserve.

if you deserve something, it is right that you get it, for example because of the way you have behaved.

After five hours on your feet you deserve a break.

anniversary.

a date when you celebrate something that happened in a previous year that is important to you.

our second wedding anniversary

statue.

a human or animal image that is made of stone, wood, metal, etc. and is usually large.

The statues represent peace and war.

neat.

carefully arranged and looking nice.

His hair was pulled back into a neat ponytail.

rubbish.

garbage.

Most of the information in her article was utter rubbish.

upper.

higher than something else, especially one of two things that are a pair.

He had a scar on his upper lip.

charity.

an organization to which you give money so that it can give money and help to people who are poor or sick, or who need advice and support.

The March of Dimes is a registered charity.

border.

the official line separating two countries or states.

border between: the border between Texas and Mexico

sticky.

a sticky substance sticks to other things.

a heavy sticky soil

lecture.

a talk to a group of people about a particular subject, especially at a college or university.

The course will be taught through a series of lectures and seminars.

rid.

to be no longer affected by someone or something that is annoying, unpleasant, or not wanted.

Just give him the money and you can be rid of him.

rare.

not happening very often.

In a rare moment of honesty, he told her what he had done.

planet.

a very large round object that moves around the Sun or another star.

planet Earth

flow.

the continuous movement of a liquid in one direction.

drugs that improve blood flow around the body

refuse.

to say you will not do something that someone has asked you to do.

Mom asked him to apologize, but he refused.

novel.

.

judge.

someone whose job is to make decisions in a court of law.

The district judge sentenced her to ninety days in prison.

literature.

stories, poems, and plays, especially those that are considered to have value as art and not just entertainment.

great works of literature

article.

a piece of writing about a particular subject that is published in a newspaper or magazine.

He has written several articles for The New York Times.

loan.

an amount of money that a person, business, or country borrows, especially from a bank.

an interest-free loan

temporary.

existing, done, or used for only a limited period of time.

These measures are only temporary.

pour.

to make a liquid or substance flow out of a container that you are holding.

pour someone something: Sit down and I’ll pour you a drink.

shade.

a slightly dark area where the light from the sun does not reach because it is blocked by something.

He pulled a wicker chair into the shade.

penny.

.

kindly.

a kindly person behaves in a kind way toward other people.

a courteous kindly gentleman

warn.

to make someone conscious of a possible problem or danger so that they will not be hurt.

warn someone to do something: Police are warning all women in the area to take extra care when going out alone.

bitter.

feeling angry or upset because of a bad experience, especially when you think that you have been treated unfairly.

bitter about: I’m still bitter about the whole affair.

stuff.

a variety of objects or things.

What’s all this stuff on my desk?

climate.

the type of weather that a country or region has.

a hot/cold/mild/warm climate: Mexico is renowned for its hot climate and spicy food.

rail.

one of the pair of metal bars that a train travels on.

We ought to transport more heavy goods by rail.

frequently.

often.

He has frequently been compared to Michael Jackson.

label.

a piece of paper or material fastened to an object that gives information about it.

Read the washing instructions on the label.

jealous.

unhappy because someone has something that you would like or can do something that you would like to do.

I expect some of your colleagues will be jealous.

shave.

to make a part of your body smooth by cutting off the hair using a razor or shaver.

I cut myself while I was shaving.

exist.

to be real, or to appear in the real world.

Dragons don’t exist.

hardly.

used for saying that something is almost not true or almost does not happen at all.

He hardly spoke except to say hello.

recover.

to become fit and healthy again after an illness or an injury.

recover from: I haven’t fully recovered from that flu I had.

compete.

to try to be more successful than other companies or people in business.

We have to compete in a commercial environment.

condition.

the physical state of something.

The survey will assess the condition of thousands of bridges.

frame.

a structure that forms a border for a picture or mirror and holds it in place.

a silver picture frame

huge.

extremely large in size.

She arrived at the airport carrying two huge suitcases.

president.

the political leader of a country that does not have a king or queen.

President Lincoln

marry.

if someone marries someone else, they are fomally joined in marriage with that person.

The day I married Sarah was the happiest day of my life.

remove.

to take something or someone away from a place.

Sally looked down at her sleeve and removed a small speck of dirt.

introduce.

to tell someone another person’s name when they meet for the first time.

Have you two been introduced?

admit.

to agree that something is true, especially when you are unhappy, sorry, or surprised about it.

Clarke admitted his disappointment at the court’s decision, but said he would fight on.

occasion.

a time at which something happens.

on one occasion  (=once): On one occasion we had to walk all the way home.

dust.

very small pieces of dirt that cover surfaces inside buildings like a powder.

The dictionaries were covered in dust.

enormous.

very large in size or quantity.

The enormous birthday cake dwarfed everything else on the table.

plenty.

a large amount of something, or a large number of things or people, usually more than enough.

We spent all day painting one side of the house, but there’s still plenty left to do.

remain.

to continue to be in a particular situation or condition.

The dictator has remained in power for over 20 years.

shape.

the outer form of something.

The room forms an L-shape.

ahead.

used when saying what will happen in the future.

ahead of: We have a busy day ahead of us.

career.

a job or series of related jobs that you do, especially a profession that you spend a lot of your working life in.

Choosing a career can be a very difficult decision.

request.

an act of asking for something in a polite or formal way.

request for: Requests for visas will be dealt with immediately.

abroad.

in or to a foreign country.

We try to go abroad at least once a year.

punish.

to make someone suffer because they have done something against the law or against the rules.

Anyone caught smoking on school premises will be punished.

worth.

if you say how much something is worth, you state its value in money.

How much do you think the house is worth?

announce.

to make a public or official statement, especially about a plan, decision, or something that has happened.

There was a press release announcing the Senator’s resignation.

promise.

to tell someone that you will definitely do something.

The police chief promised tougher action against young criminals.

grade.

one of the levels of school in the U.S. that lasts one year. Students in the same grade are all about the same age.

The topic is covered in the seventh grade.

none.

not one of a group of people, or things or no amount of something.

I thought there was some coffee in the cabinet, but there’s none there.

invent.

to design or create something such as a machine or process that did not exist before.

Alfred Nobel invented dynamite.

flood.

if water floods a place, it covers it.

Water burst through the dam and flooded local villages.

quit.

to leave a job or school permanently.

She quit after only six months on the job.

creature.

anything that lives except plants.

a small furry creature

achieve.

to succeed in doing or having what you planned or intended, usually after a lot of effort.

The Republic of Tunisia achieved independence from France in 1957.

instance.

an example of something happening.

I have not found a single instance where someone was actually denied their right to vote.

shy.

nervous and embarrassed in the company of other people, especially people who you do not know.

Archie was shy and awkward.

prince.

a male member of a royal family who is not the king, especially one whose parent or grandparent is the king or queen.

He was known as the prince of sculptors.

strike.

to hit against, or to crash into, someone or something.

One of the bullets struck her forearm.

suddenly.

quickly and without any warning.

A strange feeling suddenly came over him.

grant.

to allow someone to have or do what they want.

If permission is granted, they’ll start building soon.

FALSE.

not true.

The report was dismissed as totally false.

event.

something that happens, especially something that involves several people.

the most traumatic event of my life

option.

something that you can choose in a particular situation.

We’ve discussed all the marketing options and decided to go for television advertising.

underneath.

in, to, or through a place directly below something or directly covered by it.

I’ll leave the key underneath the mat.

remind.

to tell someone again about an event from the past or about a fact that they used to know.

I can’t think of his name – can you remind me?

realize.

to gradually begin to understand something that you did not know or notice before.

I soon realized my mistake.

promote.

to move someone to a job at a higher level.

A college course can help you find work or get promoted.

forgive.

to decide that you will not be angry with someone who has offended, upset, or harmed you.

His children have never fully forgiven him.

priest.

someone whose job is to lead worship and perform other duties and ceremonies in some Christian churches.

a Roman Catholic priest

blind.

unable to see. Some people prefer to use the expression visually impaired.

Her father is completely blind.

tight.

clothes that are tight are close against your body when you wear them.

a tight skirt/dress

scene.

a part of a play, book, movie, etc. in which events happen in the same place or period of time.

a love scene

scream.

to make a loud high cry because you are hurt, frightened, or excited.

She opened her mouth to scream.

disgusting.

extremely unpleasant.

boxes of fish that smelled absolutely disgusting

result.

something that is caused directly by something else that has happened previously.

result of: He said the incident was the result of a misunderstanding.

due.

if something is due to happen, it is expected to happen or should happen.

due to do something: The case is due to go to court next month.

certificate.

.

garbage.

.

urgent.

urgent things are things that you need to deal with immediately.

He had some urgent business to attend to.

baggage.

the suitcases, bags, etc. in which you carry your possessions when you travel.

emotional baggage

interrupt.

to say or do something to stop someone when they are speaking or concentrating on something.

Please don’t interrupt her while she’s working.

land.

an area that someone owns, often including the buildings on it. You can also refer to someone’s lands, and this has the same meaning.

The company bought the land last year.

bin.

a container for storing something, especially a large amount.

a compost bin

knowledge.

all the facts that someone knows about a particular subject.

The teacher’s comments are designed to help improve your knowledge and understanding.

reach.

to arrive somewhere.

We hoped to reach the camp before dark.

peace.

a situation in which there is no war between countries or groups.

peace in: For many years the agreement maintained peace in Europe.

allow.

to give someone permission to do or have something.

I’m sorry, sir, but smoking is not allowed.

exchange.

a situation in which one person gives another person something and receives something else of a similar type or value in return.

exchange of: The two sides agreed an exchange of prisoners of war.

former.

used for describing someone or something that had a particular job, title, status, etc. in the past, but not now.

The ceremony honored all the former presidents who are still living.

sore.

painful and uncomfortable, usually as a result of an injury, infection, or too much exercise.

a sore throat

likely.

probably going to happen, or probably true.

The most likely cause of the fire was a cigarette.

responsible.

deserving to be blamed for something that has happened.

Parents feel responsible when things go wrong.

expect.

to think that something will happen.

We’re expecting good weather this weekend.

regular.

arranged so that there is the same amount of time between events or the same amount of space between objects.

We hold regular monthly meetings.

suggest.

to offer an idea or a plan for someone to consider.

The report suggested various ways in which the service could be improved.

familiar.

well known to you, or easily recognized by you.

People are more relaxed in familiar surroundings.

habit.

something that you do often or regularly, often without thinking about it.

healthy eating habits

necessary.

essential or needed in order to do something, provide something, or make something happen.

I don’t want to be disturbed unless it’s absolutely necessary.

stupid.

not intelligent, or not able to consider or judge things carefully.

Barbara’s too stupid to understand.

blame.

to say or think that someone or something is responsible for an accident, problem, or bad situation.

If it doesn’t work, don’t blame me.

private.

used only by a particular person or group, or available only to them.

a private bathroom/party/plane

route.

a way that buses, trains, ships, or airplanes travel regularly.

the West Coast route

ground.

the top part of the Earth’s surface that people walk on.

I fell to the ground.

sense.

a strong feeling or belief about yourself.

sense of: Winning an award would give me a great sense of achievement.

replace.

to get rid of someone or something, and to put a new person or thing in their place.

We’ll have to replace all the furniture that was damaged in the flood.

advise.

to give your opinion to someone about the best thing to do in a particular situation.

I’m afraid I’m not able to advise you.

raise.

to put something in a higher place or position.

He could hardly raise the injured arm at all.

character.

the qualities that make up someone’s personality.

Stinginess with money was one aspect of Steve’s character that I didn’t like.

doubt.

a feeling of not being certain about something.

doubt about/as to: There seems to be some doubt as to whether this is legal.

trust.

a feeling of confidence in someone that shows you believe they are honest, fair, and reliable.

Trust is an important issue between teenagers and their parents.

celebrate.

to do something enjoyable in order to show that an occasion or event is special.

Let’s have a party to celebrate your birthday.

spice.

a substance made from plants and added to food to give it a particular flavor.

a blend of spices such as coriander and cumin

universe.

space and everything that exists in it, including the Earth and all the other planets.

The origins of the universe are still a mystery.

cheerful.

behaving in a happy friendly way.

Stephen was a cheerful, affectionate child.

chance.

an opportunity for you to do something, especially something that you want to do.

chance for: The meetings are very short, so there is little chance for real discussion.

permanent.

happening or existing for a long time or for all time in the future.

She suffered permanent brain damage as a result of the accident.

approach.

to move closer to someone or something.

She heard footsteps approaching from behind.

salary.

a particular amount of money that you earn each month or year from your job.

an annual salary of $45,000

horror.

a very strong feeling of shock, fear or disgust caused by something extremely unpleasant.

in horror: Millions watched in horror as the disaster unfolded on TV.

success.

the achievement of something that you planned to do or attempted to do.

Thorough preparation will increase your chances of success.

bone.

one of the hard parts that form a frame inside the body of a human or animal. This frame is called a skeleton.

She fell and broke a bone in her foot.

heaven.

the place where God is believed to live. Some people believe that good people go to Heaven when they die and bad people go to Hell.

Christians believe that Jesus ascended into Heaven.

damp.

something that is damp is slightly wet, often in an unpleasant way or when it should be dry.

a cold damp basement room

stretch.

to pull something to make it longer or wider.

I’ll have to get these shoes stretched.

outline.

to give the main ideas of a plan or a piece of writing without giving all the details.

The document outlines our company’s recycling policy.

qualify.

to have the right qualities or be in the right situation to be considered as something or to receive or do something.

be qualified to do something: Only people over the age of 18 are qualified to vote.

yawn.

.

expose.

to fail to protect someone or something from something harmful or dangerous.

expose someone/something to something: Many of the soldiers had been exposed to radiation.

emphasize.

to give particular importance or attention to something.

At school they emphasize good manners.

confidence.

the belief that you are able to do things well.

give someone confidence: Motherhood gave her confidence.

lean.

to move your body so it is closer to or farther from someone or something, for example by bending at the waist.

lean forward/back/toward/across etc.: The other girl leaned forward to hear what was going on.

broadcast.

to send out messages or programs to be received by radios or televisions.

broadcast (something) on something: The President’s speech will be broadcast on all major networks at 6:00 this evening.

reputation.

the opinion that people have about how good or how bad someone or something is.

He did not have a good reputation in his home town.

influence.

the effect that a person or thing has on someone’s decisions, opinions, or behavior or on the way something happens.

Without his famous father’s influence, he would never have been given the job.

hesitate.

to pause before doing something, or to do something very slowly, usually because you are nervous, embarrassed, or worried.

He hesitated a moment, and then knocked on the door.

courage.

the ability to do something that you know is right or good, even though it is dangerous, frightening, or very difficult.

She has shown immense courage in opposing a corrupt and violent regime.

legal.

relating to the law or lawyers.

You may wish to seek legal advice before signing the contract.

opponent.

someone who is competing against you.

You’re facing a much more experienced opponent in tomorrow’s game.

ban.

to say officially that people must not do, sell, or use something.

ban something from something: The book was banned from school libraries.

image.

an opinion that people have about someone or something, which may not be a true one.

image of: We have an image of the U.S. as a very rich country.

formal.

following the correct or suitable official methods.

The government is promising a formal investigation.

master.

a man who is very good at something.

master at: O’Sullivan is an absolute master at this type of shot.

wise.

a wise person is able to make good choices and decisions because they have a lot of experience.

Sally is a wise and cautious woman.

release.

to let someone leave a place where they have been kept.

The authorities had recently released two political prisoners.

nut.

a dry fruit that grows inside a hard shell on some types of tree and bush. Many kinds of nuts can be eaten.

Can you crack some nuts for me  (=break open the shells)?

desire.

a strong feeling of wanting to have or to do something.

ordinary human needs and desires

informal.

informal talks or meetings are relaxed, do not involve many people, and do not need to produce an official result.

The informal meetings at Camp David were important in strengthening mutual understanding and trust.

evil.

an evil person does very bad or cruel things.

a dangerous and evil dictator

enthusiasm.

the feeling of being very interested in something or excited by it.

enthusiasm for: His enthusiasm for music has stayed strong throughout his 23 years in radio.

squeeze.

to press something firmly, especially with your hands.

Ruth smiled, squeezing his hand affectionately.

appropriate.

suitable or right for a particular situation or purpose.

This isn’t the appropriate time to discuss the problem.

sympathy.

a natural feeling of kindness and understanding that you have for someone who is experiencing something very unpleasant.

The movie describes, with considerable sympathy, the problems faced by economic migrants.

aware.

knowing about a situation or a fact.

As far as I’m aware, he didn’t say anything of the kind.

impression.

the opinion that other people have about you because of the way that you look, speak, or behave.

create/make an impression on someone: As a serious candidate, you want to make a good impression on everyone you meet.

obtain.

to get something that you want or need, especially by going through a process that is difficult.

She has to obtain her parents’ permission before she does anything.

probable.

likely to happen or be true.

That is not only possible, it is probable.

citizen.

someone who has the right to live permanently in a particular country and has the right to the legal and social benefits of that country as well as legal obligations toward it.

citizen’s rights

loyal.

willing to support, work for, or be a friend to someone, even in difficult times.

They were all loyal supporters of the President.

vital.

very important, necessary, or essential.

play a vital role (in something): He played a vital role in setting up the organization.

shell.

the hard outer part that protects the body of an ocean creature.

a crab shell

adopt.

to take someone else’s child into your family and legally make him or her your own child.

The couple are hoping to adopt a baby girl.

cheat.

to behave dishonestly, or to not obey rules, for example in order to win a game or do well in an examination.

Kids have always found ways of cheating on tests.

affair.

events and activities relating to the government, politics, economy, etc. of a country, region, or the world.

a public affairs consultant

evidence.

facts or physical signs that help to prove something.

Evidence shows that global warming is definitely occurring.

muscle.

a piece of flesh that connects one bone to another and is used for moving a particular part of your body.

These exercises are good for your stomach muscles.

disaster.

something very bad that happens and causes a lot of damage or kills a lot of people.

A series of disasters forced the company to close down.

unfortunate.

experiencing bad luck, or caused by bad luck.

The unfortunate victims of the pension fund fraud are unlikely to get their money back.

decay.

to be gradually destroyed as a result of a natural process of change.

As dead plants decay, they release mineral salts into the soil.

latter.

used for referring to the second of two people, things, or groups that have just been mentioned.

He did well in both schoolwork and sports and won a number of medals in the latter  (=in sports).

spread.

to gradually affect or cover a larger area.

UN leaders hope to prevent the fighting from spreading.

appeal.

to make an urgent request for people to give you something that you need such as help, money, or information.

appeal (to someone) for something: They’re appealing to local businesses for sponsorship money.

suspicious.

believing that someone has probably done something wrong.

Colleagues became suspicious when he started acting strangely.

convert.

to change from one system, use, or method to another, or to make something do this.

You have to convert the temperature readings from Fahrenheit to Celsius.

spirit.

your attitude to life or to other people.

Compassion is only one aspect of the human spirit.

shallow.

with only a short distance from the top or surface to the bottom.

Move to the shallow end of the pool.

moral.

relating to right and wrong and the way that people should behave.

our children’s religious and moral education

guarantee.

something that makes it certain that something will happen.

guarantee of: Massive investment is no guarantee of success.

restore.

to cause a particular situation to exist again, especially a positive one.

By Sunday, electricity had been restored.

dominate.

to control something or someone, often in a negative way, because you have more power or influence.

As a boy, he was dominated by his mother.

delicate.

something that is delicate can easily be damaged or broken.

Delicate skin must be protected from the sun.

chop.

to cut something such as food or wood into pieces.

Finely chop the cabbage and cook it in boiling salted water.

sudden.

happening very quickly and without any sign that it is going to happen.

a sudden rise in violent crime

chew.

to use your teeth to bite food in your mouth into small pieces so that you can swallow it.

High-fiber foods take longer to chew.

abandon.

to leave someone when you should stay with them and take care of them.

His mother abandoned him when he was five days old.

maintain.

to make something stay the same.

Maintaining your current weight through exercise and healthy eating is important.

distribute.

to give something such as food, clothes, or money to a group of people, especially so that each person gets an equal share.

The two men were convicted of distributing antigovernment leaflets.

bush.

a plant that is smaller than a tree and has many thin branches growing close together.

a holly/rose/blackberry bush

focus.

to concentrate on something and pay particular attention to it.

I know you’re tired, but try to focus.

trap.

a piece of equipment used for catching animals.

set/lay a trap  (=make it ready to be used): We set traps in the attic for the mice.

patience.

the ability to continue doing something for a long time without losing interest, especially something difficult.

need/require patience: Wildlife photography requires a lot of patience.

struggle.

to try hard to do something that you find very difficult.
