He struggled a little at first, but he reads well now.

flame.

the brightly burning gas that you see coming from a fire.

He sat by the fire staring at the flames.

vast.

extremely large.

a vast empty plain

impress.

if someone or something impresses you, you admire them.

What impressed me was their ability to deal with any problem.

ensure.

to make certain that something happens or is done.

The lifejacket had almost certainly ensured her survival.

crack.

to damage something so that a line or long narrow hole appears on its surface, but it does not break into pieces.

I dropped a plate and cracked it.

distinguish.

to recognize the differences between things.

He learned to distinguish the songs of different birds.

victim.

someone who has been harmed, injured, or killed as the result of a crime.

a murder victim

affection.

a feeling of liking and caring about someone or something.

She has difficulty showing affection.

cure.

a medicine or treatment that makes a sick person healthy.

Doctors say there are several possible cures for the disease.

steer.

to control the direction in which a vehicle moves.

Jack steered while Ken gave directions.

rush.

to hurry in order to get somewhere very quickly.

rush in/toward/through/down etc.: Suddenly the door burst open and Joe rushed in.

fame.

the state of being famous.

Kundera achieved international fame while banned in his own country.

pressure.

attempts to persuade, threaten, or force someone to do something.

pressure for: Pressure for political change increased in the 1990s.

primary.

most important.

Dealing with crime is our primary concern.

cause.

an event, thing, or person that makes something happen.

cause of: The pathologist’s report established the cause of death as extensive chest injuries.

assist.

to help someone or something.

These measures were designed to assist people with disabilities.

deliberate.

intended, not done by chance or by accident.

I’m sure the omission of my name was deliberate.

preserve.

to take care of a place or building in order to prevent it from being harmed or destroyed.

The society works to preserve the district’s historic buildings.

nevertheless.

despite a fact or idea that you have just mentioned: used as a way of showing how a sentence, phrase, or word is related to what has already been said.

It’s a difficult race. Nevertheless, thousands of runners participate every year.

concern.

a feeling of worry about something, especially one that a lot of people have about an important issue.

concern about/over/at: Many people expressed concern over moves to restore the death penalty.

assure.

to tell someone that something will definitely happen or is definitely true, especially in order to remove doubt about it.

There’s not much more I can say to assure you.

whereas.

used for comparing two things, people, situations, etc. and showing that there is an important difference between them.

Doctors’ salaries have risen substantially, whereas nurses’ pay has actually fallen.

majority.

most of the people or things in a group.

His job is to represent the views of the majority.

highlight.

to describe something in a way that makes people notice it and think about it.

The case highlights the need for adequate controls on such experiments.

recall.

to remember something.

Twenty years later he could still clearly recall the event.

decade.

a period of ten years, especially one beginning with a year that ends in a 0, for example 1990 through 1999.

in/over/during/within the past/last/next decade: Prices have risen sharply in the last decade.

innocent.

not guilty of a crime.

Under the law, everyone is considered innocent until proven guilty.

rapid.

happening, moving, or acting quickly.

We are seeing a rapid growth in the use of the Internet.

pretend.

to behave in a particular way because you want someone to believe that something is true when it is not.

We were never going to make the marriage work, so why pretend?

major.

important, serious, large, or great.

Major roadwork ahead.

fortune.

a very large amount of money.

Jordan had inherited a considerable personal fortune from his uncle.

suffer.

to feel pain in your body or your mind.

Don’t worry, the animal won’t suffer any pain.

intelligence.

the ability to understand and think about things, and to gain and use knowledge.

a person of average intelligence

valid.

a valid document or ticket will be accepted by officials.

You will need a valid passport.

commit.

to do something illegal or morally wrong.

commit a crime/an offense: The study aims to find out what makes people commit crimes.

trial.

the process of examining a case in a court of law and deciding whether someone is guilty or innocent. When a case comes to trial, it is brought to a court and the person who has been accused of a crime stands trial  (=appears in court).

a murder/rape/fraud trial

remark.

a few words that give the facts or your opinion about someone or something.

As the chairman said in his introductory remarks, the growth of the company has been phenomenal.

brick.

a block used for building walls and other structures.

He laid every brick himself.

sufficient.

as much as is needed.

sufficient time/resources/information

combine.

if you combine things, or if they combine, you use, do, or put them together.

This product is the result of combining many different technologies.

steady.

firmly held in a particular position without moving or shaking.

Hold the flashlight steady so I can see better.

crisis.

an urgent, difficult, or dangerous situation.

financial/economic/political crisis: a period of economic/financial/political crisis

deal.

a formal agreement, especially in business or politics.

a business/peace/land deal

lane.

a narrow road, especially in the countryside.

They live down a little country lane.

lid.

a cover for a container.

a lid for the casserole dish

beyond.

outside the range or limits of a subject, quality, or activity.

Our knowledge does not extend much beyond these few facts.

launch.

to send a missile, space vehicle, satellite, or other object into the air or into space; to travel into the air or into space.

The agency will launch a new weather satellite next month.

state.

the condition of something at a particular time.

the state of: We’re collecting data on the state of the environment.

consequence.

a result or effect of something.

She said exactly what she felt, without fear of the consequences.

belief.

a strong feeling that something is true or real.

This theory goes against the beliefs of most current political thinkers.

wound.

an injury in which your skin or flesh is damaged, usually seriously. When a wound gets better it heals.

He suffered serious wounds to his back and stomach.

error.

a mistake, for example in a calculation or a decision.

error in: an error in our calculations

arrow.

a weapon in the form of a thin straight stick with a sharp point at one end and feathers at the other. Arrows are shot through the air using a bow..

Turn left with the green arrow.

manner.

the way that you do something, or the way that something happens.

manner of: The manner of his death aroused a lot of interest in the media.

calculate.

to discover a number or amount using mathematics or with a piece of equipment such as a calculator.

We’ll need to calculate the overall costs.

bend.

to lean forward and downward, or to move the top part of your body forward and downward.

He bent and kissed her quickly.

chase.

to follow someone or something quickly in order to catch them.

They were chased by photographers as they took their son to school.

contrast.

a noticeable difference between people or things.

contrast between: the contrast between her life before the accident and now

effective.

someone or something that is effective works well and produces the result that was intended.

Humor is often far more effective than shouting.

protest.

a strong complaint or disagreement.

protest at/against: The organization has made a formal protest against the nuclear testing.

feature.

an important part or aspect of something.

Each room has its own distinctive features.

swing.

to move, or to make something move, backward and forward or from one side to another, especially from a fixed point.

Swing your arms loosely at your sides.

resist.

to oppose or fight against someone or something.

The judge resisted pressure to lengthen the sentence.

artificial.

made by people and used instead of something natural.

The growers use both natural and artificial light.

chart.

a list, drawing, or graph showing information in a way that is easy to understand.

For birth rates in the 1990s, see the chart on page 247.

tail.

a part at the back of an animal’s body that can move.

The animal sprays liquid from a gland under its tail.

schedule.

a plan of activities or events and when they will happen.

What’s on your schedule today?

ultimate.

happening at the end of a process or activity.

The incident affected the ultimate outcome of the war.

breed.

if animals breed, they become the parents of young animals.

The birds have bred successfully for the past six years.

cast.

to choose a performer for a particular part or for a particular type of part in a movie, play, etc..

Ralph Fiennes was cast in the lead role of King Richard.

considerable.

large in size, amount, or degree.

a considerable amount of money

absolute.

very great, or complete: used for emphasizing an opinion, feeling, or statement.

The way they’ve been treated is an absolute disgrace.

severe.

a severe problem is very serious and worrying.

Overcrowding in California schools is pretty severe.

revolution.

a situation in which people completely change their government or political system, usually by force.

the French/Russian Revolution

indicate.

to be a sign or symbol of something.

Each pin on the map indicates a district office.

actual.

used for emphasizing what is really true or exact compared with a general idea.

The actual number of people killed is not yet known.

cloth.

material used for making clothes, curtains, etc. that is made by weaving fibers together.

linen/cotton cloth

solid.

a solid substance is firm and hard and is not a liquid or a gas.

It remains solid at room temperature.

reveal.

to let something become known, for example a secret or information that was previously not known.

She refused to reveal the contents of the letter.

establish.

to make something start to exist or start to happen.

A proper procedure for complaints should be established.

substance.

a particular type of liquid, solid, or gas.

The wood is coated with a special substance that protects it from the sun.

react.

to behave in a particular way because of something that is happening around you or something that someone is doing to you.

I wasn’t sure how you would react.

mud.

very soft wet earth.

Rain turned the road that led to the cabin to mud.

religious.

relating to religion, or to the beliefs and practices of a particular religion.

religious beliefs

estimate.

to say what you think an amount or value will be, either by guessing or by using available information to calculate it.

It’s difficult to estimate the cost of making your house safe.

theory.

one or more ideas that explain how or why something happens.

The theory predicts low speeds and therefore safety.

passage.

a long narrow area with walls on each side that leads from one room or place to another.

There was a small office leading off a passage between the kitchen and the back door.

overall.

considering something as a whole, rather than its details or the different aspects of it.

the senior police officer with overall responsibility for the case

vary.

to be different in different situations.

The details may vary, but all of these saving plans have the same basic goal.

investigate.

to try to find out the facts about something in order to learn the truth about it.

We sent a reporter to investigate the rumor.

moreover.

used for introducing an additional and important fact that supports or emphasizes what you have just said.

More and more people are opposed to the idea of increasing university fees. Moreover, there is now evidence that it discourages many students from coming to the UK.

harm.

injury, damage, or problems caused by something that you do.

projects that lead to environmental harm

feather.

.

justify.

to show that there is a good reason for something, especially something that other people think is wrong.

You’ll be expected to justify your actions.

beneath.

directly under something or at a lower level.

We took shelter beneath a huge oak tree.

finance.

decisions on how money is spent or invested.

He’s studying international banking and finance.

committee.

a group of people who represent a larger group or organization and are chosen to do a particular job, for example to study something and suggest what action to take.

the Senate Foreign Relations committee

amuse.

to do or say something that other people think is funny or entertaining.

Her stories never fail to amuse me.

client.

someone who pays for the services of a professional person such as a doctor or lawyer.

She advises clients on their investments.

institute.

an organization that does a particular type of research or educational work.

the National Cancer Institute

faint.

a faint sight, sound, smell, or taste is not strong or clear.

He could see the faint glow of a lamp through the curtains.

institution.

a large organization such as a bank, hospital, university, or prison.

a financial/educational/charitable institution

strain.

pressure caused by a difficult situation.

a strain on something: This war will put a great strain on the economy.

income.

money that someone gets from working or from investing money.

Most of the villagers rely on farming for income.

navy.

the part of a country’s military that can fight at sea.

a navy base/ship/helicopter

exception.

someone or something that is different in some way from other people or things and so cannot be included in a general statement.

New technology stocks have done badly in recent months, but Autonomy has been an exception.

rate.

the number of times something happens, or the number of examples of something within a particular period of time.

a rising birth rate

objective.

something that you plan to achieve, especially in business or work.

objective of: I’m not sure I understand the objective of this exercise.

community.

the people who live in an area.

I wanted to work somewhere where I could serve the community.

division.

the process of separating people or things into smaller groups or parts.

division of: Civil war eventually led to a permanent division of the country.

extend.

to continue for a particular distance or in a particular direction.

extend from/into/over/beyond/for etc.: The beach extends beyond the horizon.

entire.

used for emphasizing that you mean all or every part of something.

the entire adult population

urban.

relating to towns and cities, or happening there.

visible.

able to be seen.

genuine.

real, rather than pretended or false.

Morley looked at her with genuine concern.

relevant.

directly connected with and important to what is being discussed or considered.

Once we have all the relevant information, we can make a decision.

aircraft.

an airplane, helicopter, or other vehicle that flies.

military/commercial aircraft

sensitive.

reacting quickly or strongly to something.

A new generation of satellites will carry particularly sensitive instruments.

funeral.

a ceremony that takes place after someone dies, usually including a religious ceremony, and the formal process of taking the body to the place where it is buried or cremated.

He flew home to arrange his father’s funeral.

chest.

the upper front part of your body between your neck and your stomach.

a broad/hairy chest

reverse.

to change the order or development of events, a process, or a situation to be the opposite of what it was.

The effects of the disease can only be reversed by a bone-marrow donation.

anger.

the strong feeling you get when you think someone has treated you badly or unfairly, that makes you want to hurt them or shout at them.

Some people express their anger through violence.

resource.

something that you can use to help you to achieve something, especially in your work or study.

The Internet has become a valuable resource in schools.

soil.

the substance on the surface of the Earth in which plants grow.

The dry rocky soil is suitable for planting vines.

hook.

a curved piece of metal or plastic for hanging things on.

He hung his coat on a hook on the back of the door.

export.

the practice or business of selling goods to another country.

a new law controlling the export of works of art

publicity.

attention in magazines, newspapers, or television.

Her behavior on the movie set attracted a lot of free publicity.

debt.

an amount of money that you owe.

By this time we had debts of over $15,000.

remote.

far away from other cities, towns, or people.

My grandparents were from a remote town in Wisconsin.

treat.

to behave toward someone in a particular way.

She felt she had been unfairly treated, and complained to her boss.

barrier.

a bar or gate that stops people or vehicles from entering a place.

Fans broke through the barriers and rushed onto the field.

demonstrate.

to show someone how to do something by doing it yourself.

Various techniques will be demonstrated.

minister.

in some Protestant churches, someone whose job is to lead worship and perform other duties.

a meeting of trade ministers

command.

an official order.

Who gave the command to open fire?

thus.

as a result of the fact that you have just mentioned.

Fewer pupils will attend the schools, and they will thus need fewer teachers.

incident.

something that happens, especially a violent, criminal, or dangerous event.

an embarrassing incident

wire.

a long thin piece of metal like a thread.

copper/steel/gold wire

rural.

relating to parts of a country that are not near cities and where the population is low.

people who live in remote rural areas

pride.

a feeling of pleasure and satisfaction that you get when you, or someone connected with you, have achieved something special.

You could see the pride in their faces when they talked about their daughter’s acting career.

observe.

to notice someone doing something, or to notice something happening.

Similar trends may be observed in most modern societies.

shelter.

a place where people are protected from bad weather or from danger.

We built a temporary shelter out of branches.

adapt.

to change your ideas or behavior so that you can deal with a new situation.

The company was accused of being slow to adapt.

devote.

to spend a lot of time or effort doing something.

He devoted most of his time to his painting.

illustrate.

to show what something is like, or to show that something is true.

The following examples illustrate our approach to customer service.

practical.

involving or relating to real situations and events.

Applicants for the job must have at least three years of practical experience.

justice.

the fact that something is reasonable and fair.

He appealed to their sense of justice.

impatient.

annoyed because something is not happening as quickly as you want or in the way you want.

“Come on!” said Maggie, becoming impatient.

stroke.

a medical condition in which blood is suddenly blocked and cannot reach the brain, or in which a blood vessel in the brain breaks, often causing a loss of the ability to speak or to move particular muscles.

have/suffer a stroke: Leni suffered a stroke last year, and is unable to walk.

layer.

an amount or sheet of a substance that covers a surface or that lies between two things or two other substances.

Glue the layers together and let them dry.

satisfy.

to please someone by giving them something that they want or need.

an agreement that is unlikely to satisfy environmental campaigners

overcome.

to succeed in dealing with or controlling a problem.

Jimmy overcame his difficulties to graduate.

criticism.

comments that show that you think something is wrong or bad.

criticism of: He finds criticism of his team’s performance hard to take.

constant.

continuous or regular over a long period of time.

a constant flow of traffic on the freeway

response.

a reaction.

Her response was to leave the room and slam the door.

reflect.

to show the existence or nature of something.

He said that the statement did not reflect his own views.

shift.

to move your body or a part of your body slightly, for example because you are bored.

The children are shifting uncomfortably in their seats.

promptly.

immediately.

The ambulance arrived promptly.

ignore.

to not consider something, or to not let it influence you.

We had ignored the fact that it was getting darker.

suspicion.

a feeling that someone has done something wrong.

have a suspicion that: She had a suspicion that Mr. Engel was not being completely honest.

slope.

a straight surface that has one end higher than the other.

At the end of the garden there is a steep slope.

grave.

the place where a dead body is buried in a deep hole in the ground. A tomb is a structure above the ground that contains a dead body.

He’s never even visited his mother’s grave.

sweep.

to clean a floor, the ground, or another surface using a broom  (=brush with a long handle).

After you’ve swept, you can wash the dishes.

rapidly.

quickly.

Business failures have risen rapidly in recent months.

express.

to tell someone about a feeling, opinion, or goal by speaking or writing about it.

His teachers expressed concern about his progress at school.

element.

an important basic part of something complicated, for example a system or plan.

an important/essential element: Our new management system includes two essential elements.

royal.

relating to a king or queen or the members of their family.

the royal palace

seed.

a small hard part produced by a plant that can grow into a new plant of the same type.

a bag of seeds

mental.

existing in the mind.

It is clear that mental activity does not stop when we’re asleep.

affect.

to change or influence something. If something affects something else, it has an effect on it.

Did the newspapers really affect the outcome of the election?

circumstance.

a fact or condition that affects a situation.

The circumstances surrounding the child’s death are being investigated.

decline.

to become less or worse.

The number of people buying their own homes has declined.

apparent.

easy to see or understand.

apparent from: The children’s poor health was apparent from their physical appearance.

enable.

to give someone the ability or opportunity to do something.

Enemy communications were destroyed, enabling a surprise attack.

satisfaction.

the feeling of pleasure that you get when you achieve or obtain something that you want.

satisfaction from: I get a lot of satisfaction from working in the garden.

horn.

the object in a car or other vehicle that makes a loud warning noise when you press it.

honk/beep/sound your horn: A car honked its horn at me.

context.

the general situation in which something happens, which helps to explain it.

These events are meaningless outside their historical context.

emphasis.

special importance or attention that is given to one thing in particular.

emphasis on: The main emphasis should be on quality rather than quantity.

enthusiastic.

very interested in something or excited by it.

Business leaders gave an enthusiastic welcome to the proposal.

awkward.

difficult to deal with and embarrassing.

After he spoke there was an awkward silence.

steam.

the hot wet substance like a thin cloud that is produced when water is heated.

The steam from the volcano rose into the air.

represent.

to speak or act officially for another person, group, or organization.

Ambassador Albright will represent the United States at the ceremony.

occur.

to happen, especially unexpectedly.

The police said that the accident occurred at about 4:30 p.m.

measure.

an action that is intended to achieve or deal with something.

This is a temporary measure to stop the problem from getting any worse.

govern.

to control and manage an area, city, or country and its people.

The region is now governed by Morocco.

examine.

to look at something carefully in order to find out about it or see what it is like.

She opened the suitcase and examined the contents.

disturb.

to interrupt someone and stop them from continuing what they were doing.

I didn’t want to disturb you in the middle of a meeting.

acid.

a chemical substance with a pH value  (=a measure used in chemistry) of less than 7.

hydrochloric acid

scratch.

to pull your nails along your skin, especially because you have an itch that makes you want to do this.

define.

to describe clearly and exactly what something is.

No one has defined the scope of the project.

process.

a series of things that happen and have a particular result.

We use drugs to speed up the healing process.

physical.

relating to your body rather than your mind.

The emotional and physical strain of the previous day had left him exhausted.

poison.

a substance that can kill you or make you sick if you eat, drink, or breathe it.

Some mushrooms contain poison.

collapse.

if a building or other structure collapses, it suddenly falls down.

There were fears that the roof would collapse.

wealth.

a large amount of money and other valuable things.

They used some of their wealth to build magnificent town halls.

heal.

if an injury heals, the skin or bone grows back together and becomes healthy again.

The wound took a long time to heal.

vision.

the ability to think about and plan for the future, using intelligence and imagination, especially in politics and business.

He’s a good day-to-day manager but he lacks vision.

substantial.

large in amount or degree.

emerge.

to come out of something or out from behind something.

emerge from: After a few weeks, the caterpillar emerges from its cocoon.

contribute.

to give money, goods, or your time and effort in order to achieve something, especially when other people are also helping.

contribute to: Many local businesses offered to contribute to the school rebuilding fund.

witness.

someone who sees a crime, accident, or other event happen.

Witnesses reported hearing two gunshots.

relief.

a relaxed happy feeling that you get because something bad has not happened or a bad situation has ended.

It’s a huge relief to know that everyone is safe.

device.

a machine or piece of equipment that does a particular thing.

Secure your bike with this simple locking device.

publication.

the process of producing a book, magazine, etc., either on paper or online, for people to buy or read.

publication of: She became famous after the publication of her first novel.

anxiety.

a worried feeling you have because you think something bad might happen.

current.

happening or existing now.

adjust.

to change something slightly in order to make it better, more accurate, or more effective.

Stir in the lemon juice and adjust the seasoning.

unique.

very special, unusual, or good.

You will be given the unique opportunity to study with one of Europe’s top chefs.

rub.

to press and move your hands or an object over a surface.

The boy rubbed his eyes sleepily.

aspect.

a particular part, feature, or quality of something.

aspect of: a system of rules that covers almost every aspect of their lives

tackle.

to make an organized and determined attempt to deal with a problem, often a social problem such as crime or unemployment.

expand.

to become larger in size and fill more space.

The water froze inside the pipe, causing it to expand and burst.

proof.

information or evidence that shows that something is definitely true or definitely exists.

proof of: We were unable to establish proof of her innocence.

slight.

small in size, amount, or degree.

a slight increase in temperature

oppose.

to disagree with or not approve of a plan or policy.

a group that opposes the death penalty

weapon.

an object that can be used to hurt people or damage property, for example a gun, knife, or bomb.

The murder weapon still hasn’t been found.

signal.

a movement or sound made by someone that has a special meaning to another person.

signal to: He gave a signal to his driver to carry on.

gentleman.

a man who is always polite and honest and considers other people’s needs.

Everyone always said that James was a real gentleman.

swear.

to use words that are deliberately offensive, for example because you are angry with someone.

That’s the first time I’ve ever heard him swear.

occupy.

if someone occupies a room, building, area of land, seat, bed, or other place during a period of time, they use it.

The Smith family has occupied this farm for over a hundred years.

purchase.

to buy something.

She purchased a number of different stocks.

construct.

to build something large or complicated, such as a bridge or road.

The tunnel was constructed in 1996.

whistle.

a small metal or plastic object that you put in your mouth and blow to make a high sound.

blow a whistle: The referee blew the whistle for half-time.

monitor.

to regularly check something or watch someone in order to find out what is happening.

a special machine to monitor the baby’s breathing

council.

the elected officials who govern a local area such as a city or county.

a member of the city council

supply.

an amount or quantity of something that is available to use.

debate.

a discussion in which people or groups state different opinions about a subject.

debate about/on/over: There has been intense debate over the handling of illegal immigrants.

propose.

to suggest a plan, idea, or action.

Einstein proposed his theory of general relativity in 1915.

offend.

to make someone upset and angry by doing or saying something.

They avoided saying anything that might offend their audience.

elegant.

elegant places and things are attractive because they are beautiful in a simple way.

an elegant silk dress

joy.

a feeling of great happiness.

There were tears of joy in her eyes.

strength.

the physical energy that someone has to lift or move things.

I didn’t have the strength to get out of bed.

sweat.

liquid that forms on your skin when you are hot.

She wiped the sweat off her forehead with a towel.

deny.

to say that you did not do something that someone has accused you of doing.

deny (that): A spokesman denied that the company had acted irresponsibly.

needle.

a very thin sharp metal tube used for putting medicine or drugs into your body, or for taking blood out. It is attached to a plastic tube called a syringe.

hypodermic needles

dishonest.

willing to do things that are not honest, for example tell lies or steal things.

They admitted that there were dishonest officers in the police force.

phase.

a particular period of time during the development of something.

The war was about to enter its final phase.

explosion.

an occasion when something bursts with a lot of force and a loud noise, often causing damage.

a gas/nuclear explosion

structure.

something large such as a building or a bridge that is built from different parts.

The boulevard is lined with modern steel and glass structures.

import.

a product from another country, that is bought with money from your country.

China must produce more food to reduce its reliance on imports.

criticize.

to say what you think is wrong or bad about something.

Cabinet members were told not to criticize the policy publicly.

smash.

to break something noisily into many pieces by dropping or hitting it with a lot of force.

Someone had smashed a window.

destruction.

damage that is so severe that something stops existing or can never return to its normal state.

The building must be saved from destruction.

absorb.

to take in a gas, liquid, or other substance.

approximate.

not exact, but close to an exact amount, number, time, etc..

the approximate cost of repairs/time of death

respond.

to react to something by taking a particular course of action.

respond to: Colleges responded swiftly to the demand for new courses.

function.

the job that something is designed to do.

The function of advertising is to create a unique image for your company.

generate.

to make money.

origin.

the place or moment where something begins to exist.

origin of: Meteorites may hold clues about the origin of life on Earth.

capture.

to catch someone so that they become your prisoner.

Most of the men had been either killed or captured.

wander.

to travel from place to place, especially on foot, without a particular direction or purpose.

He wandered the countryside, looking for his son.

failure.

a lack of success in doing something.

I’m too proud to admit failure.

mass.

a large quantity or number.

mass of: We need to turn this mass of evidence into a coherent argument.

safety.

the fact that a thing is safe to do or use.

safety of: Do we know enough about the safety of these vaccines?

cell.

the smallest part of a living structure that can operate as an independent unit. The middle of a cell is called the nucleus.

nerve/blood/brain/cancer cells

tradition.

a very old custom, belief, or story.

Native American culture and traditions

manufacture.

to make goods in large quantities in a factory.

The firm manufactures women’s clothing.

significant.

very large or noticeable.

joint.

involving two or more people, or done by them together.

The two presidents issued a joint statement.

tend.

to usually do a particular thing.

tend to do something: He tends to exaggerate.

curve.

a shape or line with a gradual smooth bend.

From high above I saw the gentle curve of the bay.

impact.

an effect, or an influence.

Her paper discusses the likely impact of global warming on climate change.

independence.

freedom from control by another country or organization.

Lithuania was the first of the Soviet republics to declare its independence.

absence.

a period of time when someone is not where they should be or where they usually are.

His frequent and prolonged absences were making his wife suspicious.

conduct.

to do something in an organized way.

The rental agreement doesn’t allow you to conduct business from your home.

odd.

unusual or unexpected in a way that attracts your interest or attention.

Harry’s behavior did seem a little odd.

string.

thin rope, usually made of twisted fibers and used for tying things together.

a package tied with string

chief.

main or most important.

The majority of the market has gone to their chief rival, Gateway.

capable.

able to do something.

capable of: I want to see you achieve what you are capable of.

craft.

a traditional skill of making things by hand, for example furniture or jewelry.

the promotion of traditional Egyptian arts and crafts

steel.

a strong metal made from a mixture of iron and carbon.

The factory produced a million tons of steel a year.

survive.

to stay alive despite an injury, illness, war, etc..

Just eight passengers survived the plane crash.

expense.

an amount of money that you spend in order to buy or do something.

Rent is our biggest expense.

gather.

if people gather, or if someone gathers them, they come together in one place to see or do something.

A crowd gathered outside the hotel.

settle.

to end an argument by making an agreement.

We are going to settle our differences, once and for all.

desperate.

very worried and angry because you do not know how to deal with an unpleasant situation.

The missing man’s family is getting increasingly desperate.

insult.

an offensive remark.

throw/hurl insults at someone: He stormed off the field, hurling insults at the umpire.

melt.

to change a solid substance into a liquid.

Melt the butter in a small saucepan.

massive.

very large or heavy.

the massive columns at Luxor

immediate.

happening or done now, without any delay.

Our government must take immediate action.

appreciate.

to understand the true nature of a situation, and realize why it is important or serious.

presence.

the existence of someone or something in a particular place.

Mr. Reese didn’t even acknowledge my presence.

armed.

carrying a weapon, especially a gun.

policy.

a set of plans or actions agreed on by a government, political party, business, or other group.

contemporary.

modern, or relating to the present time.

contemporary art/music/literature/dance

philosophy.

a system of beliefs that influences someone’s decisions and behavior.

the latest philosophies of management

violence.

violent behavior.

identify.

to recognize someone and be able to say who they are.

Two of the suspects have been identified by witnesses.

confuse.

to make someone feel that they do not understand something.

mayor.

the most important elected official in a town or city.

abuse.

cruel, violent, or unfair treatment, especially of someone who does not have the power to prevent it.

concrete.

based on facts and information.

Do you have any concrete evidence to support these allegations?

claim.

to say that something is true, even though there is no definite proof.

claim (that): The report claimed that hundreds of civilians had crossed the border to escape the fighting.

stare.

to look at someone or something very directly for a long time.

It’s rude to stare.

estate.

all the property and money that belongs to someone, especially someone who has just died.

Martin was the sole heir to his father’s estate.

specific.

involving or relating to only one particular thing or type of thing.

Spectators are only allowed into specific areas of the stadium.

emotion.

a feeling that you experience, for example love, fear, or anger.

Jealousy is an uncomfortable emotion.

cease.

to stop happening or continuing.

Conversation ceased when she entered the room.

authority.

the power to make decisions or tell people what to do.

In practice it is difficult for the President to exercise his authority.

senior.

with a high rank or position.

a senior officer/teacher/manager

profit.

money that you make by selling something or from your business, especially the money that remains after you have paid all your business costs. Your total profit before you pay tax is called gross profit, and the amount that remains after you have paid tax on this is called net profit.

Profits rose 31% to $144 million.

internal.

existing or happening within a country, not between different countries.

an internal flight

personality.

the part of a person that makes them behave in a particular way in social situations, for example in a friendly or unfriendly way, or in a confident or shy way. You use the word character when you are talking about whether someone is good or bad, or honest or dishonest.

He has a very outgoing personality and makes friends very easily.

alter.

to make something or someone different.

He altered his appearance with surgery.

interpret.

to translate what someone is saying in one language into another language so that someone else can understand it.

I speak Spanish. Would you like me to interpret for you?

scheme.

a plan for achieving something, especially something illegal or dishonest.

adequate.

good enough or large enough for a particular purpose.

dare.

if you dare to do something, you are not afraid to do it, even though it may be dangerous or shocking or may cause trouble for you.

cardboard.

.

thorough.

including everything that is possible or necessary.

suspect.

to believe that something is true, especially something bad.

Teachers should call social services if they suspect child abuse.

task.

something that you have to do, often something that is difficult or unpleasant.

ease.

to make a problem, bad situation, or pain less severe.

Sometimes a mild painkiller is enough to ease the pain.

loss.

the state of not having something anymore because it has been taken from you or destroyed.

It was an ancient car anyway, so it was no great loss.

priority.

something important that must be done first or needs more attention than anything else.

fence.

.

invest.

to use your money with the goal of making a profit from it, for example by buying property or buying stock in a company.

How much do you have to invest?

seek.

to ask for something, or to try to get something.

seek advice/help: Seek medical advice if symptoms last more than a week.

surface.

the top layer or outside part of something.

a smooth/rough/hard surface

force.

physical strength, or violence.

They accused the police of using excessive force during the arrest.

source.

a person, place, or thing that provides something that you need or want.

a light/power/energy source

violent.

involving the use of physical force, with the deliberate intention of causing damage to property or injury or death to people.

There were violent confrontations on the streets last night.

scale.

the size of something, especially when it is big.

scale of: Is the Government aware of the full scale of the problem?

award.

a prize or other reward that is given to someone who has achieved something.

She won the Player of the Year award.

assume.

to believe that something is true, even though no one has told you or even though you have no proof.

mixture.

a combination of two or more different things, people, qualities, etc..

mixture of: Her face showed a mixture of fear and excitement.

precise.

exact and accurate.

acquire.

to get something, for example by buying it or being given it.

obey.

to do what a law or a person says that you must do.

budget.

the amount of money a person or organization has to spend on something.

lung.

.

extreme.

very great in degree.

extreme poverty/hardship

gradual.

gradual processes and changes happen slowly and by small amounts.

a gradual change in the climate

crucial.

something that is crucial is extremely important because it has a major effect on the result of something.

We believe the question being investigated by the Commission is one of crucial importance to the country.

tough.

difficult.

He’s having a really tough time at the moment.

conscious.

noticing that something exists or is happening and realizing that it is important.

conscious of: Teachers are increasingly conscious of the importance of the Internet.

praise.

to express strong approval or admiration for someone or something, especially in public.

Mayor Dixon praised the efforts of those involved in the rescue.

belong.

to be in the right place.

When you’re done put the books back where they belong.

global.

including or affecting the whole world.

extent.

the size and importance of a problem or situation.

extent of: We were shocked by the extent of the damage.

definite.

certain.

trace.

to find someone or something that you are looking for by asking questions and getting information.

burst.

if something filled with air or water bursts, or if you burst it, it breaks suddenly because there is too much pressure inside it or against it.

Did a tire burst?

cope.

to deal successfully with a difficult situation or job.

balance.

the ability to remain steady in an upright position.

faith.

strong belief in or trust of someone or something.

extension.

extra time that you are given to finish a piece of work, especially at college.

facility.

something such as a room or piece of equipment that is provided at a place for people to use.

county.

a region that has its own local government in some countries such as the U.K. and U.S..

immoral.

morally wrong.

entitle.

rear.

at the back of something.

angry disagreement between people or groups.

a particular quality or feature that is typical of someone or something.

military.

relating to armies or armed forces and the way in which they are organized.

delight.

a feeling of great happiness and pleasure.

delight in: Joe’s delight in his children’s achievements was beautiful to see.

to use something new or different instead of what is normally used.

ridiculous.

silly or unreasonable and deserving to be laughed at.

a ridiculous idea

pace.

the speed at which something happens or is done.

accuse.

to say that someone has done something wrong or committed a crime.

accuse someone of doing something: Are you accusing me of lying?

secure.

to get or achieve something important.

threat.

an occasion when someone says that they will cause you harm or problems, especially if you do not do what they tell you to do.

threat of: After threats of legal action they stopped the construction.

encounter.

a meeting, especially one that was not planned.

I had not seen her since our brief encounter two years before.

whisper.

to say something very quietly so that other people cannot hear you.

“When can I see you again?” he whispered softly.

disapprove.

to not approve of someone or something.

She wanted to confide in Alan, but was frightened he might disapprove.

basis.

a particular method or system used for doing or organizing something.

on a...basis: workers who are employed on a temporary basis

punishment.

a way in which someone is punished.

He had to clean up the mess as a punishment.

amaze.

to surprise someone very much, especially by being very impressive.

These guys continue to amaze with their excellent music.

crown.

a circular decoration that a king or queen wears on their head as a symbol of power, often decorated with jewels.

France will be defending their World Cup crown.

etc.

used after a list of things to mean “and others of the same type,” when you do not want to mention everything.

The children can try playing music, dancing, painting etc.

multiply.

to increase by a large amount.

Within the last 10 years, both sales and profits have multiplied.

polish.

to rub the surface of something in order to make it shine.

They spend most of their time polishing shoes.

tool.

a piece of equipment, usually one that you hold in your hand, that is designed to do a particular type of work.

kitchen/garden/dental tools

abstract.

abstract ideas exist as thoughts in the mind, and are not related to physical objects or real events and actions.

abstract idea/concept/principle/notion: Mathematics is concerned with understanding abstract concepts.

ancestor.

someone who is related to you who lived a long time ago.

Her ancestors came to America with the Pilgrims.

bare.

a part of your body that is bare is not covered by any clothes. When someone is not wearing any clothes at all, they are naked or nude.

She wore a low-necked dress and her arms were bare.

commercial.

relating to business.

a commercial transaction

donate.

to give something such as money or goods to an organization, especially to a school, hospital, political party, or charity.

The center was bought with money donated by former Beatle, George Harrison.

earthquake.

.

flexible.

able to make changes or deal with a situation that is changing.

A more flexible approach to childcare arrangements is needed.

legend.

an old story about famous people and events in the past. Legends are not usually true.

the legend of the Headless Horseman

poisonous.

containing poison.

poisonous gases/plants

tray.

a flat piece of plastic, metal, or wood with raised edges, used for carrying things such as plates or food.

She brought in glasses of cold lemonade on a silver tray

vanish.

to disappear in a sudden and mysterious way.

One moment she was there, the next she had vanished.

worm.

.

suicide.

the action of deliberately killing yourself.

commit suicide  (=kill yourself): Police believe he committed suicide.

vinegar.

.

prejudice.

an unreasonable opinion or feeling, especially the feeling of not liking a particular group of people.

the evils of prejudice

yell.

to say something in a loud voice, or to make a loud noise because you are angry, afraid, excited, or in pain.

yell at: Her husband was yelling at her.
